metadata.title: Supplemental hot melt extruded nano-selenium increases expression profiles of antioxidant enzymes in the livers and spleens of weanling pigs

sections.text:
Contents lists available at ScienceDirect
Animal Feed Science and Technology
journal homepage: www.elsevier.com/locate/anifeedsci
Supplemental hot melt extruded nano-selenium increases expression profiles of antioxidant enzymes in the livers and spleens of weanling pigs
JunHyung Leea,1, Abdolreza Hosseindousta,1, MinJu Kima, KwangYeol Kima, YoHan Choia, SeokHee Leea, SongYi Leeb, HyunJong Chob, ByungJo Chaea,* a College of Animal Life Sciences, Kangwon National University, Chuncheon 24341, Republic of Korea b College of Pharmacy, Kangwon National University, Chuncheon, Gangwon 24341, Republic of Korea
A R T I C L E I N F O
Keywords: Glutathione peroxidase Antioxidant Weanling pigs Selenium supplement
A B S T R A C T
A study was conducted to determine the effect of dietary selenium (Se) concentration and source for weanling pigs on serum Se, glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity and performance. A total of 120 weanling pigs with an average weight of 6.87±0.4 kg were assigned to 4 diets with 10 pigs per cage and 3 replicates per treatment. The experimental diets were fed for 28 days in 2 phases (phase 1, d 0–14; and phase 2, d 15–28). Treatments were: Control (without Se supplementation), sodium selenite (INO; 0.30 ppm), hot melt extruded sodium selenite (HME; 0.30 ppm), and selenomethionine (ORG; 0.3 ppm). There were significant responses (P<0.05) for higher serum Se concentration in the HME and ORG treatments in phase 1 and 2. The serum GPx analyses revealed that supplemental HME and ORG significantly increased the concentration of GPx in the serum in phase 1 and phase 2. There was an up-regulated (P<0.01) expression of Selenoprotein W, GPx1, GPx3, GPx4, and GPx5 in the livers of the HME and ORG pigs. In conclusion, the HME and ORG Se showed increased antioxidant status, consequently being a more suitable source of Se than regular sodium selenite.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Selenium (Se) is one of the essential trace minerals involved in various biological activities of animals. Selenium deficiency impairs the activity of several antioxidant enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase (GPx) (Diplock, 1992; Dalgaard et al., 2018). Selenium is widely supplemented in diets for swine because the majority of common feed ingredients are marginally deficient in Se (Surai and Fisinin, 2016). The dietary Se supplement has been mainly based on the inorganic source in the form of sodium selenite due to relatively low cost. Although the NRC (2012) recommends 30 mg/kg of dietary Se for weanling pigs, the supplementation of Se at levels above the requirement, particularly during the stressful periods, is a common practice to reduce the possibility of Se deficiency and optimizing the growth performance under commercial conditions (Gan et al., 2014). Weaning is the most critical stage of pig production when the deficiency of Se is likely to occur due to enteric infections (Surai and Fisinin, 2016; Kim et al., 2017; Dalgaard et al., 2018). However, in recent years, the high dietary supplementation of minerals has been a subject of considerable environmental contamination concern due to excess mineral excretion. Therefore, the search is being increased to find alternative
https://doi.org/10.1016/j.anifeedsci.2019.114381 Received 31 May 2019; Received in revised form 9 November 2019; Accepted 17 December 2019
⁎ Corresponding authors. E-mail address: bjchae@kangwon.ac.kr (B. Chae). 1 These authors contributed equally to this work.
Animal Feed Science and Technology xxx (xxxx) xxxx
0377-8401/ © 2019 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.
Please cite this article as: JunHyung Lee, et al., Animal Feed Science and Technology, https://doi.org/10.1016/j.anifeedsci.2019.114381
options such as nano or organic supplements (Kim and Mahan, 2001; Wang and Xu, 2008; Zhan et al., 2007). Nano-size particles were found to have higher bioavailability owing to higher activity and specific surface area (Boostani et al., 2015). However, the efficacy of nanoparticles and the rate of bioavailability may be related to the kind of nano process. The affinity of inorganic minerals to solvents such as water is low; therefore, thermodynamic process is essential to maximize the dispersion of minerals in solvents. The dispersion stability of nano-sized particles in the final product may affect the bioavailability of minerals. The hot melt extrusion (HME) is known to be one of the best environmentally friendly techniques that has been developed for nanoparticle trace elements production in the pharmaceutical industry (Lee et al., 2017). Furthermore, the uniformity of Se dispersion during the HME process is attributed to the source of the incorporated polymer matrix. The solubility and dispersion of poorly watersoluble items increase by applying copolymers as the binder of dry or wet granulation (Lee et al., 2017). In the HME process, the raw materials homogeneously mix into the extruder through a rotating screw towards the die in a high temperature. The barrels temperature mainly designs to be above the glass transition temperature of polymeric substances, to be able to disperse the materials molecularly in the polymer matrix. This technique has to our knowledge not been exploited as yet in the swine feed industry. We hypothesized that Se nanoparticles prepared by the HME process can improve the absorption of Se in weanling pigs and thus be more efficient in comparison to traditional inorganic Se. The aim of the current study was to investigate the effects of nano and organic Se on antioxidant status, organ gene expression, growth performance, and nutrient digestibility, on weanling pigs.

sections.heading: 2. Materials and methods
sections.text: The protocol for the present experiment was approved by the Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee of Kangwon National University, Republic of Korea.

sections.heading: 2.1. Preparation of HME selenium
sections.text: Na2SeO3, Span 80, Tween 80, and polyethylene glycol 6000 were mixed at 20:12:4:64 ratio prior to feeding process. That processed mixture was moved to the feed hopper at a 45 g/min speed. Twin-screw system worked with hot-melt extruder (STS-25HS, Hankook E.M. Ltd., Pyeongtaek, Korea) connected with a round-shaped die (1 mm diameter) was used for the preparation of extruded materials (Lee et al., 2017). The temperatures of barrel and die section were maintained 45 °C and 40 °C, respectively. The speed of the screw was 150 rpm during HME process. By passing through conveying and kneading sections in the barrel, samples were extruded from the die section. Extruded substances were solidified and they were milled by the HBL-3500S grinder (Samyang Electronics Co., Gunpo, Korea). The particle properties of Na2SeO3 nano-particles dispersed in distilled water (DW) were elucidated. The hydrodynamic size, polydispersity index, and zeta potential of Na2SeO3 nano-particles were measured by dynamic light scattering (DLS) and laser Doppler methods (ELS-Z1000; Otsuka Electronics, Tokyo, Japan). Powder of Na2SeO3 extrudate was dispersed in DW at 20 mg/mL and their particle properties were tested. The particle shape of Na2SeO3 extrudate was observed by transmission electron microscopy TEM. The dispersion of Na2SeO3 nano-particles was loaded onto the copper grid with film and dried for 10 min. That sample was then observed by TEM (JEM 1010; JEOL, Tokyo, Japan). The morphological shape of Na2SeO3 was measured by transmission electron microscopy (JEM 1010; JEOL, Tokyo, Japan). The final product was a white powder and the particle sizes were ranged from 28 to 59 nm.

sections.heading: 2.2. Animals and experimental design
sections.text: A total of 120 weanling pigs (Landrace × Yorkshire × Duroc; average weight 6.87± 0.4 kg) were randomly allotted on the basis of initial BW according to a randomized complete block design in the Research Center of Animal Life Sciences at Kangwon National University. There were 3 replicates in each treatment with 10 weanling pigs per replicate. The treatment included: Control (without Se), Inorganic Se (INO, 0.30 ppm Se), nano-Se (HME 0.30 ppm Se), and selenomethionine (ORG, 0.30 ppm Se). The experimental diets were fed for 28 days in 2 phases (phase 1, d 0–14 and phase 2, d 15–28). The diets were formulated to provide all of the nutrients to meet or exceed the nutrient requirements listed in the NRC (2012) with the exception of Se (Table 1). The pigs used in the study were housed in partially slotted and concrete floor pens with a pen size of 2.80 m × 5.00 m. All the pens were equipped with a self-feeder and nipple drinker to allow ad libitum access to feed and water.

sections.heading: 2.3. Selenium determination
sections.text: Selenium content in the feed, feces, liver, and serum was determined on the dissolved ashes using inductively coupled plasma emission spectroscopy (ICP) according to the methods of AOAC (2007; AOAC (2007; method 2011.19). The current study feed and excreta samples were measured in triplicates for Se determination and 1 g of ground feed, liver, and fecal samples were dry ashed for 1 h in a muffle furnace at 600 °C. Then, the ashed samples were allowed to cool, dissolved by adding 10 mL 50 % HCl (v/v) and kept in overnight with covered. The samples were filtered using Whatman filter paper in a 100 mL flask known as volumetric flask by washing crucibles 2–3 times and diluted with deionized distilled water and Se concentrations were measured by ICP. Serum samples, 1 mL samples were measured in porcelain crucibles and oven dried for 4 h at 105 °C and then ashed for 1 h at 600 °C in a muffle furnace. The samples were filtered using Whatman filter in a 100 mL flask known as volumetric flask by washing crucibles 2–3 times and diluted with deionized distilled water and Se concentrations were measured by ICP.

sections.heading: 2.4. Glutathione peroxidase activity
sections.text: To determine the GPx activity, a spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan) and colorimetric assay kit (BioVision) were used according to the manufacturer’s protocol. In brief, cumene hydroperoxide and oxidized glutathione catalyzed by serum GPx was used as substrates of reaction with NADPH and measured at OD 340 nm. The reduction of the determined NADPH is proportional to the GPx bioactivity.

sections.heading: 2.5. Blood, slaughtering, and tissues sampling
sections.text: At day14 and 28, four pigs per replicate were randomly selected for the collection of blood. Blood samples were collected via the jugular vein and ethylene diamine tetra acetic acid (EDTA) tube and serum separate (SST) tube were used. Then, those samples were centrifuged (Union 32R, Bucheon, Korea) at 3000 rpm at 4℃ for 15 min to obtain the serum. White blood cells (WBC) and red blood cells (RBC) were analysed using an automatic blood analyser (ADVIA 120, Bayer, NY). At day 28 of the feeding trial, 2 pigs per replicate were chosen as representative samples and were slaughtered to collect tissue samples. The Livers and spleens samples were obtained and frozen directly in liquid nitrogen and stored at -80℃ to await analysis.

sections.heading: 2.6. RNA extraction and real-time PCR
sections.text:
Total RNA was isolated from the livers (50 mg) and spleens (100 mg) samples via RNAiso plus kit (Takara Biotechnology, Japan) according to manufacturer’s instruction. The samples were resuspended in DEPC (diethyl pyrocarbonate)-treated water. The quality and quantity of RNA were evaluated through electrophoresis in 1.0 % (w/v) formaldehyde denaturing agarose gel. The prepared RNA
concentration was evaluated by Nanodrop 1000 (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA) and OD260/OD280 ratio was approximately 1.8-2.0. To reverse-transcribe with refined RNA into the cDNA, the first strand cDNA synthesis kit (Takara Co. Ltd, Japan) was used by manufacturer’s instructions. In this process, house-keeping gene, β-actin was introduced to adjust the quantity of input cDNA as maintain the role in internal control. To determine mRNA levels, real-time PCR analysis was conducted with SYBR Premix EX Taq (Takara Co. Ltd, Japan) used in ABI 7500 Real Time PCR System by manufacturer’s instructions. The primer sequences (Table 2) for this real-time PCR analysis were prepared by Primer 5.0 software with E. coioides cDNA sequences from GenBank. A total of 20 μL reaction system included 10 μL SYBR Premix Ex Taq, 0.8 μL of forward and reverse primer (10 μM), 0.4 μL ROX Reference Dye II (50×), 2.0 μL cDNA template, and 6 μL dd H2O. Cycling conditions were as follows: 30 s at 95 °C, 40 cycles of denaturation step at 95 °C for 3 s, 60 °C annealing step for 34 s and a 72 °C extension step for 15 s. All measurements were performed in duplicate and the result was normalized by using β-actin to optimize the relative gene expression of the treatments and control samples. The cycle threshold (Ct) values were determined for each gene based on the reference gene. Relative gene expression was evaluated using the 2- ΔΔCt method.

sections.heading: 2.7. Growth performance and nutrient digestibility
sections.text: Pigs were weighed individually, and feed consumption was calculated at the end of each experiment to calculate average daily gain (ADG), average daily feed intake (ADFI) and gain to feed ratio (FCR). To determine the effect of different treatments on the apparent total tract digestibility (ATTD), chromic oxide (2.50 g/kg) was added in each diet and fecal grab samples were collected during the last four days of each phase of the experiment to determine the ATTD of dry matter (DM), gross energy (GE) and crude protein (CP). Pens were cleaned before the start of sample collection and the fecal samples were then pooled within the pen, dried in a forced air oven at 60 °C for 72 h, grounded in a Wiley mill (Thomas Model 4 Wiley Mill, Thomas Scientific, Swedesboro, NJ) using a 1-mm screen and used for chemical analysis. Analysis for each sample was done in triplicate for DM (Method 930.15), CP (Method 990.03), ash (Method 942.05), calcium and phosphorus (method 985.01; 16) according to the methods of AOAC (2007). The gross energy of diets and excreta were measured using a bomb calorimeter (Model 1261, Parr Instrument Co., Molin, IL), while chromium concentrations were determined (Fenton and Fenton, 1979) with an automated spectrophotometer (Shimadzu, Japan).

sections.heading: 2.8. Statistical analysis
sections.text: Statistical analysis of the current experimental data was completed by using the GLM procedure of SAS (SAS Inst. Inc., Cary NC) in a randomized complete block design. Pen replicate was the experimental unit for all measurements. Treatment means were separated by Turkey multiple range tests at P<0.01 statistical level.

sections.heading: 3. Results
sections.text:
3.1. Blood Profiles and Se concentration in the liver
The effects of dietary Se source on blood profiles are presented in Tables 3 and 4. There was an increase in the concentration of serum Se in HME and ORG pigs in phase 1 and 2. There were no variations in blood WBC and RBC concentrations among Sesupplemented treatments. An increased GPx concentration of serum occurred in HME and ORG pigs compared with the control pigs. There was an increased (P<0.01) Se concentration of the livers in HME pigs (Fig. 1). Moreover, the concentration of Se in the livers were higher (P<0.05) in INO and ORG pigs than that of the control pigs.
SelW, selenoproteinW; GPx, glutathione peroxidase.

sections.heading: 3.2. Gene expression of selenoproteins
sections.text:
The effects of dietary Se sources on gene expression are presented in Fig. 2. Weanling pigs fed diets supplemented with the HME had the highest (P<0.01) gene expression of selenoprotein W (SELW), GPx1, and GPx3 in the liver. In addition, the HME and ORG pigs showed an up-regulated expression of GPx-4 compared with the INO and control pigs. There was no significant difference in the livers GPx2 gene expression among the treatments. An up-regulated expression of (P<0.05) GPx5 was observed in weanling pigs fed with ORG Se diet compared with the HME, INO, and control diets.
The expression of SELW, GPx1, GPx2, GPx3, GPx4, and GPx5 in the spleens were higher (P<0.01) in HME and ORG weanling pigs than that of the control weanling pigs. An up-regulated expression of (P<0.05) SELW, GPx2, GPx4, and GPx5 in the spleens were observed in weanling pigs fed with INO Se diet compared with the control diet.
WBC, white blood cell; RBC, red blood cell; INO, sodium selenite; HME, hot melt extruded sodium selenite; ORG, selenomethionine. a∼bMeans values with different superscripts with same row differ (P < 0.05).
1 Standard error of means.
INO, sodium selenite; HME, hot melt extruded sodium selenite; ORG, selenomethionine. a∼cMeans values with different superscripts with same row differ (P < 0.05).
1 Standard error of means.

sections.heading: 3.3. Growth performance
sections.text: Growth performance data are presented in Table 5. In phase 1, there was an improvement (P<0.05) in ADG and ADFI in HME and ORG pigs. In phase 2, Dietary supplementation of Se showed no change in ADG and ADFI among the treatments. There was no variation in FCR between the treatments during the experiment. In addition, there were no variations in digestibility of dry matter, crude protein, and gross energy among the treatments in both phases (data now shown).

sections.heading: 4. Discussion
sections.text:
One of the main aims of the present study was to evaluate the bioavailability of different Se sources in weanling pigs. The increase in the supplemented doses of Se was reflected in Se concentration of serum (Jang et al., 2010; Dalgaard et al., 2018) or liver (Jang et al., 2010; Falk et al., 2018). Se is absorbed from the intestine and subsequently transported to the bloodstream, as serum Se was higher in HME or ORG pigs. Selenomethionine as an organic Se absorbs via methionine transporters and convert to selenide in the liver to provide Se for selenoprotein synthesis (Juniper et al., 2009; Falk et al., 2018). The previous literature confirmed the use of organic sources such as selenomethionine is superior to inorganic sources (Kim and Mahan, 2001; Jang et al., 2010; Dalgaard et al., 2018). In contrast, considering the mentioned aspects, the result of this study does not confirm the superior role of ORG and not only no difference was observed between inorganic Se-HME and ORG in serum Se concentration, but also a lower concentration of Se in
Fig. 2. (A) Fold change in mRNA level of the selenoprotein W (SELW), glutathione peroxidase 1 (GPx1), glutathione peroxidase 2 (GPx2), glutathione peroxidase 3 (GPx3), glutathione peroxidase 4 (GPx4), and glutathione peroxidase 5 (GPx5) genes of the livers in treated pigs with dietary inorganic selenium (INO), nano-selenium (HME), and organic selenium (ORG) supplements compared to the control pigs. (B) Fold change in mRNA level of the SELW, GPx1, GPx2, GPx3), GPx4, and GPx5 genes of the spleens in treated pigs with dietary selenium supplements compared to the control pigs. Data were normalized to the β-actin gene. Each value represents the mean of twelve pigs± SD. Different letters show significant difference between the treatments (P<0.05).
the liver was observed in the ORG pigs compared with HME pigs. Therefore, our study can reject the hypothesis that the bioavailability of Se increases in the organic form due to the use a different absorption pathway. Instead, the particle size can be considered as a more important factor. The types of nano process and the applied polymer may effectively define the absorption efficiency of particles due to a high variation in the reported results in the literature (Zhan et al., 2007; Surai and Fisinin, 2016; Skalickova et al., 2017). The chemical (Shi et al., 2011), biological (Hu et al., 2012; Forootanfar et al., 2014), and physical (Quintana et al., 2002) techniques have already been applied to produce nano-particle Se. Each technique may own its mode of action and in our study the chemical polymers effectively increased the absorption of Se. These results are in agreement with previous findings in absorption efficiency of nano-particles (Lee et al., 2017). Nano-size particles have been indicated to increase the efficiency of absorption owing to small particle size and high surface area. Interestingly, no difference was found in serum Se between the control and INO pigs in spite of their substantial variation in Se intake. It is well known that the liver markedly regulates the blood metabolites, and the serum Se concentration for INO treatment may be regulated faster than HME due to lower concentration.
Selenium status is commonly evaluated by several indicators. Even though serum concentrations of Se will reflect the short term changes, it still is widely applied in the references to be an indicator of Se status (Baltić et al., 2015; Dalto et al., 2018). In addition to serum Se, the activity of Se-GPx is considered as a frequently used factor of long-term immune and antioxidant status (Chen et al., 2016; Dalgaard et al., 2018). We studied the effect of different Se sources on antioxidant status of weanling pigs and found that the serum GPx of HME and ORG pigs was higher than that of serum GPx from the control pigs. The Se availability directly affects the activity of GPx (Dalto et al., 2018), however, there is a complex relationship between the activity of Se-GPx and dietary Se, particularly when the amount of serum Se is the maximum for adequate Se-GPx production. The increase in serum GPx in HME and ORG pigs are similar to the previous findings on GPx concentration in serum of pigs, in which the GPx expression increased in organs from either the inorganic Se (Zhan et al., 2007; Falk et al., 2018) or organic Se (Jang et al., 2010; Falk et al., 2018). Selenium is responsible for the diverse antioxidant functions and biological pathways by regulating the Se-depended antioxidant enzymes and whole body glutathione synthesis (Diplock, 1992; Dalgaard et al., 2018). The significant differences in serum GPx between pigs fed the control and Se-supplemented diets are an expected result due to the strongly related connection between the activity of GPx and Se, but the higher GPx in HME pigs compared with INO pigs may be related to the smaller particle size of Se and the increased absorption.
GPx family is a reliable biomarker of low Se status in animals (Surai and Fisinin, 2014). GPxs are well known for the antioxidant function by removing potentially damaging radicals (Pisoschi and Pop, 2015; Surai and Fisinin, 2016). The gene expression of GPx in the livers and spleens was increased in weanling pigs fed dietary Se. The comparison between the sources of Se showed relatively a higher livers GPX-1, GPx-3, and SelW expression in HME pigs, but a higher GPx-5 expression for ORG. Further, among eight GPxs in mammals, GPx1 is the most prevalent selenoprotein in animals, working as a strong antioxidant factor to control the toxic effects of H2O2 and decrease oxidative damage of cells (Lubos et al., 2011; Dalgaard et al., 2018). Given that GPx1 account for the highest share of the body selenoproteins (Reeves and Hoffmann, 2009), the highest expression of GPx1 in the livers of HME pigs may be an important factor to show the higher bioavailability of Se. In addition, the GPx expression in INO pigs is much lower than our expectation compared with HME and ORG pigs. As we mentioned before, the synthesis of selenoproteins is regulated by the presence of Se, and the reduced bioavailability of Se limits anti-oxidative activity response. The production of selenoproteins can be triggered by hydrogen selenide as a substrate derived from sodium selenite by thiols reductions (Skalickova et al., 2017). The GPx’s are collectively the primary factor for signaling and detoxification of free radicals such as H2O2 with an integral role to maintain endogenous cellular redox homeostasis (Reeves and Hoffmann, 2009; Pisoschi and Pop, 2015; Skalickova et al., 2017). It has been reported that the form of Se as inorganic or organic is associated with the magnitude of GPx activity (Boostani et al., 2015; Falk et al., 2018). Our findings on the increased GPx activity can be supported by the research of Gan et al. (2014) who indicated a higher GPx activity in the livers of pigs fed high levels of Se. It is well documented that the antioxidant status is proportional to the body Se pool.
ADG, average daily gain; ADFI, average daily feed intake; FCR, feed conversion ratio, INO, sodium selenite; HME, hot melt extruded sodium selenite; ORG, selenomethionine. a∼bMeans values with different superscripts with same row differ (P < 0.05).
1 Standard error of means.
The nutrient requirements of swine (NRC, 2012) recommend 0.3 ppm Se for weanling pigs. Recommendations for dietary Se, are mostly according to the maximum serum GPx activity. Till date, little work has been done on the relationship between Se level of diet and the saturation of serum GPx and the possible effects of serum antioxidant capacity on the growth performance of pigs.
It was noted that supplementation of Se is required for optimal growth (Pinto et al., 2012). In the present study, the Se-supplemented diets at 0.3 g/kg did not modify the overall ADG, FCR or ADFI of pigs compared to the control group. However, the ADG of HME and ORG pigs were improved in phase 1, indicating that the Se requirement of pigs during the stressful weaning period may be higher than the standard recommended requirements at a younger age than older age. Dietary Se mitigated the effects of stressors such as aflatoxin (Hao et al., 2016) and heat stress (Liu et al., 2016) on barrier integrity of the intestine and mRNA expression of GPx1, associated with a decrease in oxidative stress in pigs. The higher ADFI or improved immune status may explain the higher ADG in the first phase. Comparing the effect of the three different Se sources along the first phase of the experimental period (1–14 days) shows that the HME and ORG Se sources were more effective than the INO at 0.3 ppm/kg of diet. Organic minerals use a different absorption pathway, and HME may increase the intestinal absorption due to the role of smaller particle size. Particle size is a determinant parameter to increase the absorption efficiency (Shi et al., 2011). The smaller size of nanoparticles (around 200 nm) allows Se to be absorbed through the intestinal mucus barrier (Kachuee et al., 2019). Interestingly, no association was found between the FCR and digestibility of nutrients in the first phase in spite of the significant contribution of Se to increased ADG. A limitation of our study is the use of only a single Se dose because this was a comparative experiment based on different Se sources, and we cannot recommend the best dose of Se for weanling pigs in different phases. Moreover, an accepted optimal dose has not been recommended for nano-Se and appropriate dietary level for Se is still under debate. The price difference of nanoparticle or organic sources compared to the common inorganic source has restricted their use in the diets. However, apart from the economic cost, critical problems with regard to the environmental issues should take into consideration in diet production. Therefore, it is necessary for the swine industry to apply highly absorbable Se to reduce environmental pollution.
In conclusion, the weanling pigs fed the HME or ORG diets exhibited an increased glutathione peroxidase in immune organs, indicating a higher oxidant capacity compared with the INO and control. According to the result of Se concentration in the liver, it can be stated that the nano-Se is absorbed and preserved more effectively than the organic source. According to the growth performance results, higher doses of Se are recommended during the first two weeks of the weaning period.
Declaration of Competing Interest
The authors declare that they have no competing interests.

referenceMentions.context: Selenium deficiency impairs the activity of several antioxidant enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase (GPx) (Diplock, 1992; Dalgaard et al., 2018).
Selenium deficiency impairs the activity of several antioxidant enzymes such as glutathione peroxidase (GPx) (Diplock, 1992; Dalgaard et al., 2018).
Selenium is widely supplemented in diets for swine because the majority of common feed ingredients are marginally deficient in Se (Surai and Fisinin, 2016).

Although the NRC (2012) recommends 30 mg/kg of dietary Se for weanling pigs, the supplementation of Se at levels above the requirement, particularly during the stressful periods, is a common practice to reduce the possibility of Se deficiency and optimizing the growth performance under commercial conditions (Gan et al., 2014).
Weaning is the most critical stage of pig production when the deficiency of Se is likely to occur due to enteric infections (Surai and Fisinin, 2016; Kim et al., 2017; Dalgaard et al., 2018).

In addition to serum Se, the activity of Se-GPx is considered as a frequently used factor of long-term immune and antioxidant status (Chen et al., 2016; Dalgaard et al., 2018).

The Se availability directly affects the activity of GPx (Dalto et al., 2018), however, there is a complex relationship between the activity of Se-GPx and dietary Se, particularly when the amount of serum Se is the maximum for adequate Se-GPx production.

Selenium is responsible for the diverse antioxidant functions and biological pathways by regulating the Se-depended antioxidant enzymes and whole body glutathione synthesis (Diplock, 1992; Dalgaard et al., 2018).

Selenium is responsible for the diverse antioxidant functions and biological pathways by regulating the Se-depended antioxidant enzymes and whole body glutathione synthesis (Diplock, 1992; Dalgaard et al., 2018).
GPx family is a reliable biomarker of low Se status in animals (Surai and Fisinin, 2014).
GPxs are well known for the antioxidant function by removing potentially damaging radicals (Pisoschi and Pop, 2015; Surai and Fisinin, 2016).
GPxs are well known for the antioxidant function by removing potentially damaging radicals (Pisoschi and Pop, 2015; Surai and Fisinin, 2016).

Further, among eight GPxs in mammals, GPx1 is the most prevalent selenoprotein in animals, working as a strong antioxidant factor to control the toxic effects of H2O2 and decrease oxidative damage of cells (Lubos et al., 2011; Dalgaard et al., 2018).

Further, among eight GPxs in mammals, GPx1 is the most prevalent selenoprotein in animals, working as a strong antioxidant factor to control the toxic effects of H2O2 and decrease oxidative damage of cells (Lubos et al., 2011; Dalgaard et al., 2018).

Given that GPx1 account for the highest share of the body selenoproteins (Reeves and Hoffmann, 2009), the highest expression of GPx1 in the livers of HME pigs may be an important factor to show the higher bioavailability of Se.
The production of selenoproteins can be triggered by hydrogen selenide as a substrate derived from sodium selenite by thiols reductions (Skalickova et al., 2017).

The GPx’s are collectively the primary factor for signaling and detoxification of free radicals such as H2O2 with an integral role to maintain endogenous cellular redox homeostasis (Reeves and Hoffmann, 2009; Pisoschi and Pop, 2015; Skalickova et al., 2017).

It has been reported that the form of Se as inorganic or organic is associated with the magnitude of GPx activity (Boostani et al., 2015; Falk et al., 2018).
It has been reported that the form of Se as inorganic or organic is associated with the magnitude of GPx activity (Boostani et al., 2015; Falk et al., 2018).
It was noted that supplementation of Se is required for optimal growth (Pinto et al., 2012).
Dietary Se mitigated the effects of stressors such as aflatoxin (Hao et al., 2016) and heat stress (Liu et al.
, 2016) and heat stress (Liu et al., 2016) on barrier integrity of the intestine and mRNA expression of GPx1, associated with a decrease in oxidative stress in pigs.
Particle size is a determinant parameter to increase the absorption efficiency (Shi et al., 2011).
The smaller size of nanoparticles (around 200 nm) allows Se to be absorbed through the intestinal mucus barrier (Kachuee et al., 2019).

metadata.abstractText: A study was conducted to determine the effect of dietary selenium (Se) concentration and source for weanling pigs on serum Se, glutathione peroxidase (GPx) activity and performance. A total of 120 weanling pigs with an average weight of 6.87±0.4 kg were assigned to 4 diets with 10 pigs per cage and 3 replicates per treatment. The experimental diets were fed for 28 days in 2 phases (phase 1, d 0–14; and phase 2, d 15–28). Treatments were: Control (without Se supplementation), sodium selenite (INO; 0.30 ppm), hot melt extruded sodium selenite (HME; 0.30 ppm), and selenomethionine (ORG; 0.3 ppm). There were significant responses (P<0.05) for higher serum Se concentration in the HME and ORG treatments in phase 1 and 2. The serum GPx analyses revealed that supplemental HME and ORG significantly increased the concentration of GPx in the serum in phase 1 and phase 2. There was an up-regulated (P<0.01) expression of Selenoprotein W, GPx1, GPx3, GPx4, and GPx5 in the livers of the HME and ORG pigs. In conclusion, the HME and ORG Se showed increased antioxidant status, consequently being a more suitable source of Se than regular sodium selenite.
metadata.creator: Elsevier
